entry.title: What to Read When You Grew Up with the Baby-Sitters Club
entry.content:

Entertainment

Curated by our editorsStories to fuel your mind

What to Read When You Grew Up with the Baby-Sitters Club

therumpus.net · 7 min

There’s something special about the Baby-Sitters Club—something that compels those of us who grew up with it (or who are just discovering it today) to fully geek out when we find each other.

The Investigative Reporting Behind America’s Obsession With Britney Spears’ Conservatorship

ProPublica · 9 min

How Loki built a different reality with retro hardware

The Verge · 6 min

Jason Sudeikis Is Having One Hell of a Year

GQ · 23 min

The story behind the iconic Vietnam episode of 'Hey Arnold!'

NBC News · 7 min

Popular with Pocket readersStories from across the web

‘I was addicted to the high’: I became an influencer as a joke – then it nearly broke me

The Guardian · 16 min

Comedian Bella Younger thought wellness Instagrammers were ripe for parody. Soon she was drawn in herself. Could Deliciously Stella find her way back to reality?

Kate Winslet Has No Filter

The New York Times · 15 min

The star of ‘Mare of Easttown’ is back on the sides of buses. Without airbrushing.

How TikTok Chooses Which Songs Go Viral

Bloomberg · 7 min

The app’s hits seem to emerge organically, but the success of artists like Megan Thee Stallion reveals a highly managed curation process.

The Music Industry Is Finally Scaring Spotify

Slate · 17 min

The music business is booming again, thanks to streaming—and musicians are fighting for a bigger, better piece of the pie.

Is rewatching old TV good for the soul?

BBC · 11 min

With the amount of new shows to choose from reaching overwhelming levels, increasingly audiences are choosing to rewatch their favourite series instead. David Renshaw explores why.

‘Summer of Soul’ Review: In 1969 Harlem, a Music Festival Stuns

The New York Times · 7 min

Stevie Wonder, Mahalia Jackson, Mavis Staples and others shine in a documentary about the Harlem Cultural Festival from Questlove. There’s no shortage of system shocks in “Summer of Soul.

Pocket’s 10 Most-Saved Stories in June 2021

Pocket · 2 min

What COVID did to friendship, the health benefits of coffee, and more.

How SoundScan Changed Everything We Knew About Popular Music

The Ringer · 18 min

Thirty years ago, Billboard changed the way it tabulated its charts, turning the industry on its head and making room for genres once considered afterthoughts to explode in the national consciousness Elton John twice. Stevie Wonder. Bruce Springsteen. Michael Jackson. Whitney Houston. That’s it.

Why it’s nearly impossible to buy an original Bob Ross painting

thehustle.co · 8 min

The famed TV artist was one of history’s most prolific painters. But you’re not likely to find his work on the open market.

TikTok and the Vibes Revival

The New Yorker · 10 min

Increasingly, what we’re after on social media is not narrative or personality but moments of audiovisual eloquence.

Why Don’t Some TV Shows Sound the Way They Used To?

The New York Times · 7 min

Licensing issues have gutted the soundtracks of many beloved series on streaming services, resulting in bewildering music cues and missing theme songs.

Screams, slashers and Thatcher: why horror films are going back to the 80s

The Guardian · 3 min

From Netflix’s Fear Street to UK shocker Censor, a new wave of gory tales are being set in the recent past – but what can they tell us about the present?

The Redemption of Justin Bieber

GQ · 25 min

He made every mistake a child star can make, including the ones that nearly destroyed him. Now—fortified by God, marriage, and a new album, Justice—Justin Bieber is putting his life back together, one positive, deliberate step at a time.

The Best Movie Performances of the Century So Far

The New Yorker · 20 min

The best cinematic performances don’t share some standard of craft or technique; what they have in common is a feeling of invention and discovery, of emotional depth and power, and a sense of self-consciousness regarding the idea and the art of performance itself.

The Pulp and Pleasure of ‘Raiders of the Lost Ark,’ 40 Years Later

The Ringer · 11 min

Watching the action-adventure classic today is like going on a treasure hunt for traces of the film’s original influences—the dime store novels and pulp fiction stories—that are largely lost on the generation that grew up with it.

A real turn-off: are celebrities ruining podcasting?

The Guardian · 8 min

From Obama and Springsteen to Paris Hilton and the Duke and Duchess of Sussex, famous folk can’t stop hogging the mic.

Introducing Bistro Vibes, the Throwback Lifestyle for the Happily Washed

GQ · 8 min

Vintage Porsches, smoked salmon pizza, double-breasted blazers: your parents' cheesy signifiers are back, and they've never felt cooler.

John Swartzwelder, Sage of “The Simpsons”

The New Yorker · 32 min

The first major interview with one of the most revered comedy writers of all time.

The greatest achievements in Dumb Internet Video

Polygon · 9 min

As you can imagine, there was an impossible number of possibilities to choose from.

The Beatles: Get Back—An Exclusive Deep Dive Into Peter Jackson’s Revelatory New Movie

Vanity Fair · 17 min

This fall Disney+ unveils the three-part documentary, which mines long-lost footage for a portrait of the band’s final chapter that’s so unexpected it surprised even Paul McCartney.
